There's a marked difference in the planes from the interior displays to the exterior and while I understand the weather can be hard on them, it would be nice to see the larger outdoor exhibits better cared for.
I enjoyed the visit and had a good time explaining the history surrounding the planes to my kids, but it may be some time before I return.
Being an Air Force brat and seeing lots of places. This is in the top 3 in the nation. #1 being the Air Force Museum in Dayton. The next one may be this or the annex for the Smithsonian

For anyone interested in the history of flight, this is a great place to spend an afternoon. They even have an SR71C Blackbird - the only one of its type ever made, and it has a rude nickname.
Once or twice a year they have events where you (or your grandkids) can sit in the cockpits of some of the planes. Busy days, but worth it.
The museum itself is in two parts; an outdoor area where the *really* big planes are, and the indoor area, which is mainly fighters and helicopters. I recommend you try to go during the spring/summer, when the weather is nice enough to wander outside.
Highly recommended.
What a great find. The volunteers were knowledgeable and friendly. Great exhibits and history. Well worth spending an afternoon or morning

We took our children and grandchildren there for a visit. Everyone loved it and thought the displays of memorabilia, planes, and exhibits were very informative and interesting. It was in July, but the rooms were kept cool and comfortable for the many visitors. I would love to go back and see more someday!
_source.review_title: A wonderful place to learn some important history.

_source.comment: Good price and very interesting for kids! Nice to visit in the summer months when the weather is warm! You can get great pictures!

Took my boys ages 7 and 5. We started outside where you could walk around and look at the different types of planes. Some were so huge and it was crazy to be standing right next to them and seeing how small you are in comparison. The boys loved it! The only thing they were disappointed with is the fact that they couldn't go inside any of them. There are a lot of them and it can be quite a walk, so bring some water if it's a hot day. They have paved sidewalks all throughout, so you can bring strollers or wagons for little ones. We then went inside the museum building where there is a small gift shop and a room with other planes and other things to look at. They had replicas of nuclear bombs which was fascinating to see. It opened up opportunities to talk to my kids about war and the men and women that serve our country and protect our freedom. There is no admission fee to see any of this, but they have places where you can put in donations to help with the upkeep of this attraction. They also have volunteers there to answer any of your questions. Was a fun morning and would highly recommend.
_source.review_title: Standing next to those big planes is amazing!

_source.comment: We took our young grandchildren, ages 4 & 7, to see the museum after our grandson spotted the outdoor plane exhibit from I-15. We started with the two indoor exhibit halls, then went outside to see the planes around the grounds. There were easily more adults there than children, so don't be put off if you're traveling without kids. The museum is free, the gift shop offers a nice selection of airplane-related gifts, and there are bathrooms in the main building. If you're planning to stay a while, especially in the summer, pack cold drinks as there are none sold in the store and the only soda machine outside was out of service. As a bonus, the outdoor area offers a great view of the Wasatch Mountains. Oddly, the elderly museum volunteers were cranky on the day we visited. Overall, we had a good time.
It's free!!! Its FUN and its great for all ages. It has a lot of fun facts that you may or may not know about planes, war, military. Kids love it, and adults do too!!!
_source.review_title: A Must see in the Top of Utah

_source.comment: Hill Aerospace Museum is one of the must see places for our grandchildren when they visit every summer. Seeing the planes up close and reading the related history gives them hours of entertainment while learning about this branch of our country's military and their service to the country.

I've lived in this area for over 15 years and had never visited this museum until this summer. I must say, I was shocked at the size of the buildings and the amount of planes on display. Everything was very close up and labeled so that you knew what it was. The museum is nicely laid out and there are even mannequins in period costumes around some of the exhibits. The thing I found most interesting, oddly enough, wasn't a plane, it was a display on Vietnam POWs. They had a replica of a cell at the Hanoi Hilton, along with stories of men who'd served at Hill Air Force Base before (or since) being captured in Vietnam. It was a very interesting story and I enjoyed the way that display was set up very much. I'm not sure I'd give this an overly enthusiastic recommendation for children. My daughter (10) was entertained for about an hour, but after that, she was wanting to leave.

The Hill Aerospace Museum is located on approximately 30 acres on the northwest corner of Hill Air Force Base, about five miles south of Ogden. The museum was founded in 1981 as a part of the United States Air Force Heritage Program and first opened in 1986. It moved to its current facility in 1991.
The Museum exhibits more than 90 military aircraft, missiles, and aerospace vehicles on the grounds and inside the Major General Rex A. Hadley Gallery and the Lindquist Stewart Fighter Gallery.
The list of aircraft on display is extensive. The collection also includes a wide variety of ordnance and munitions, an assortment of aerospace ground equipment, rockets, military vehicles, uniforms, and thousands of other historical artifacts.
We highly recommend a visit to the museum for aviation enthusiasts, and anyone with an interest in vintage aircraft and the United States Air Force history. It truly is an incredible facility well worth visiting.
It is conveniently located just off I-15 at Exit 338, Roy Exit. A gate pass onto Hill AFB is NOT required to visit the museum. Simply take Exit 338 (east) off Interstate 15 in Roy, Utah, and enter the museum grounds through the gate.
Also housed in the museum is an extensive, well-stocked gift shop. Food service is not provided onsite.
Parking and admission is free.
On our last visit in May of 2013, we spent nearly three hours in the museum. But the exhibits are so extensive and well done, that one could easily spend an entire day, and not see everything.

I visit aircraft museums whenever available in each city we travel to during our summer Odysseys. This is one of the finer displays of aircraft in the intermountain west. Very well done with an abundance of volunteers to assist with any questions that may arise. Well worth the visit.

If you are a lover of aircraft, this is the museum for you. Situated at the periphery of Hill Air Force Base in Layton, Utah, this museum has an extensive collection of aircraft, starting with earliest flights until late 20th century. The planes are arranged in chronological order and many are accompanied by recorded descriptions, photos and videos. The entrance fees are low, and during the summer several free days are available. Our young grandsons enjoyed this museum.
_source.review_title: Excellent collection of vintage air raft

_source.comment:
We were very surprised to find such an excellent museum in a small town in Utah, even one near a major Air Force Base.
The museum displays an array of aircraft spanning the history of Air Force, from its origins as the Army Air Corps in WWII to the present, from a B17 to a SR71Blackbird, one of the few on display anywhere.
In addition to planes, there are a number of informative exhibits featuring period specific uniforms and other information about the history of aviation.
This gem of a museum was a pleasant discovery and a great way to spend a morning or an afternoon in Layton. You will learn a lot about history and come away with a greater respect for the men and women who have served our nation over the years.

I took my boys, along with the Scouts to the museum last summer and we all loved it. From the bombers and jets outside, to the fantastic items inside. I loved the old bi-planes and my favorite - the B-17! I think that the boys would have loved to stay longer, but we could only stay for 3 hours before we had to head back. Even then I think we saw more than enough. I think that a few trips would be very worthwhile - especially for anyone who has a love of historical and military aircraft.
I remember my first visit as a scout, where our scoutmaster took us up to a F-4 Phantom and proceeded to tell us stories of his time flying them in 'Nam'. Our recent experience was led by a volunteer from the airbase who was being deployed the next day. He was an actual pilot and the boys loved to hear him talk of his experiences.
We will be back soon

Going from not flying at all to sending rockets to the moon and beyond has almost all happened during my lifetime. But military aircraft has largely been developed secretely surrounded by mystery, myths of Alliens, and unbelievable achievement. To be able to see examples of this development upclose and touchable is to me more exciting, thrilling, and inspiring than to watch the most are out and futuristic movie about air and space travel. Anything can be done in the movies through models, art work and computers. But what you see at the Hill Air Force Base Museum WE ACTUALLY DID. To see it makes one proud to be a member of the human race. I thank the people at Hill Air Force Base for assembling such a breath-taking array of these aircrafts, and organize and maintain them for us to see that WE REALLY DID IT! (I wonder what unbelievable "marvels" are on the drawing boards or evening being flight test as we marvel at what we see at this great museum. If you are even close the it, DON'T MISS IT!
_source.review_title: See the amazing history of American military aircraft up close and touchable

_source.comment:
My son is an airplane/military aficionado. This stop on our trip was completely for him (16). And he and my hubby loved it. My daughter (13) and I spent the time downloading photos into my laptop (we've had to do these stops before and, frankly, when you've seen one plane, you've seen them all if you're not interested in them).
Planes, planes, planes. I don't know the specific models, but the boys took lots of pictures. There aren't many places for the "significant others" to sit and wait. I think they spent about an hour and a half looking at the planes (we knew we were on a tight schedule, so they may have rushed through the museum thinking they might run out of time). The staff/volunteers seemed very knowledgable and even suggested another museum he may like. That was super helpful since I never know what to look for in these things.
We decided to wait in a room that was dark (to preserve the artifacts), cool and not as busy. Turned out it was a flight suit exhibit - those were interesting for us to look at.
Admission is free (or by donation).
_source.review_title: The boys loved it! The girls... not so much.

_source.comment: The collection of aerospace items in this facility staffed by veterans will take alot of time that could not be better spent to see. Come early in the morning to see the static displays and then the hot portion of the day visiting the interior of the two buildings.
We were there in February and walked around through several buildings inside. Just a super bunch of variety of planes in here and worth a couple of hours of your time if you are visiting the area.
_source.review_title: Pretty interesting and mostly indoors, nice!

_source.comment:
We live near this museum and I have been taking my children (ages 7 and 5) here regularly for several years. This museum has two large hangars full of airplanes representing the history of flight from the Wright brothers to the F-16. Planes from all of the major wars in the last century are represented. There is also a large yard in front with many more planes to see up close. My grandpa piloted a B-24 in WWII and I like seeing that plane with my kids and sharing their history with them. The volunteers are friendly and knowledgeable. Best of all, there is no charge to enjoy the museum, though donations are gratefully accepted.
There is an Education Room in the back hangar where kids can play with science toys. It isn't open all the time, so check in advance if you want to be sure it will be open for your visit. For younger kids there are traditional toys and for older kids (and adults) there are flight simulators and computers. Once last summer a volunteer helped helped us make paper rockets that we then took outside and shot into the air.
Tripadvisor's Ogden address for this attraction threw me off a little. This museum is inside Hill Air Force Base, just west of I-15 near Roy, a smaller city just south of Ogden. You can easily see this museum from the freeway, especially if you are travelling from the south.

Hill Air Force Base Museum is conveniently located on Interstate 15 about 35 miles north of Salt Lake City. For anyone interested in military aircraft, the Museum displays a very large collection of U.S. Air Force aircraft from about 1940 to 2000.
The collection includes famous aircraft from the Cold War period including the B-52, B-47, F-102, F-4, C-124, and many others. The collection includes notable World War II aircraft inculding the B-29, B-24, B-17, P-40, P-51, P-47, and P-38.
The large aircraft are displayed outdooors, where they unfortunately show the effects of weather. Smaller and fully-restored aircraft are displayed inside two large air-conditioned buildings where they are well protected but unfortunately parked so close to one another it is sometimes difficult to fully appreciate the aircraft. There are a large number of displays of missles, aircraft engine cut-aways, etc. Admission is free. Access to the Museum is very convenient, because it is adjacent to, but not enclosed in, the active Air Force Base, so there are no difficult admission procedures.
One of the most interesting displays focuses on women pilots who served in World War II, mainly ferrying aircraft. I was surprised and saddened to learn that many of these women faced a great deal of hostility from male fliers, mechanics, etc. It is sad that people had time for that pettiness while trying to fight such a major war.
_source.review_title: very extensive Air Force museum north of Salt lake City

_source.comment:
My husband and I took our 9 year old son here on September 2, 2007 while en route from Brigham City to Salt Lake City. The museum is located by the Hill Air Force base. Our son is very interested in World War II and military aircraft. He very much enjoyed the museum as did myself and my husband!
This museum houses dozens of renovated military aircraft, from the Wright Flyer to WWII planes and newer jet fighters such as an F-15 and a Blackbird. There are indoor and outdoor exhibits (the larger planes are located outdoors, such as the B-52 bomber). The complete listing of aircraft is on the museum's website. Outside we also saw aircraft landing at the Air Force base which was cool.
There are informative displays about each aircraft and even a small military uniform display. Volunteers are on staff to provide insight about the various aircraft. Since my son appeared very into the museum we were given a very thorough tour of the museum by two volunteers, which we enjoyed very much and found very informative.
The museum and parking are free and open 7 days a week. I would definitely recommend this museum to military aircraft and history enthusiasts.

Not as extensive as the Air and Space Museum at Dulles airport in the DC area, but still lots of aeronautical history that has been maintained well. If you are a military airplane buff, it's worth visiting.

I was impressed by the quality of this art museum on the University of Utah Campus. It is located in the Marcia and John Price Building on campus.
There are different sections in the gallery focusing on high quality art. Much of the art I knew and was impressed by the selection. They have art that focuses on the ancient and classical world, European and American masterworks, Asian art, art of Utah and the American West, and modern and contemporary art. My personal favorite was the art of Utah and the American West which had some stunning pieces.
There is an admission charge to the galleries.
One can park for free across the street from the Utah Museum of Fine Arts. The parking places are highlighted. One does need to register the car's license plate with the staff at the ticket desk at the gallery.
_source.review_title: High Quality Art collection - Utah Museum of Fine Arts

_source.comment:
Incredibly impressed by this museum. Wide variety of art from around the world tastefully and professionally displayed and curated.
On the University of Utah campus which is also beautiful.
Very nice gift shop and small but seemingly popular cafe.

My wife is the artist. We go to a lot of museums. We spent a good two hours here. Facility and overall environment of UMFA was wonderful. Two stories, with elevator. Great cafe and gift shop. Art included Asian, Pacific, African, Europe, American and more. Parking is free.
_source.review_title: Very Enjoyable and Worth a Visit

_source.comment: Great venue for wedding plus able to wander around the art exhibition between wedding breakfast and evening reception

It's fun to go here on Free museum days (First Wednesdays and Third Saturdays). The third Saturdays also have special craft activities that you can participate in. They are aimed for families and children, but I often enjoy decorating clay plates, making a sculpture, etc as well. The museum staff is very friendly and explains the exhibits that are going on.
UMFA is well-curated, and even though it doesn't have any singular stand alone pieces, it is does have some beautiful works by famous artists such as Renoir and Singer-Sargent. These master works are combined with unique exhibits such as Mayan pottery, Spanish art, and an Egyptian sarcophagus room. It is well worth the low price of admission (especially on aforementioned free days).
Let it be said that I actually like the streamer room. Sure, it could probably be used for a lot more art in the large hall, and it isn't my favorite Feher piece, but it is pretty awesome to have a Feher piece at all. His work is certainly modern contemporary, which many people don't appreciate; that's fine. But he is one of the biggest names in the US of this generation, and the pink streamers are just another example of his simple trademark colorful design. For the people that don't appreciate the neon pink streamers - at least he didn't paint an entire city lot pink here as he did in New York.
There is also a small cafe in the front where you can get cookies, scones, and coffee, which is a great way to end your visit, or hang out while the kids are doing crafts or listening to stories.
The parking is the one thing that leaves more to be desired, but if you go on the weekend there is plenty of free parking since permits aren't enforced.
_source.review_title: One of my favorite museums in Salt Lake

_source.comment: The museum is located on the University campus, easy access from my downtown hotel via the SLC light rail system. The museum collection is interesting and varied and the exhibits are well curated.. The western art holdings in particular are excellent and varied, and the temporary exhibits were fantastic. Allow several hours. I had lunch at the museum cafe, delicious food and very friendly service, sat outside on the patio enjoying the mountain view. Great afternoon.

We have visited the UMFA a few times for special exhibits. Recently we had wanted to see the exhibit on the Bingham Canyon mine. It was very well done, including works from the museum's collection along with borrowed works from various sources. It piqued an interest in us about the process of curating a special exhibit.
I would suggest that parking could be better marked and explained. The building itself is great with easy access. There is a cafe available, although we did not eat there. We took a quick walk through the gift shop and found it to be very interesting, having some unique items for sale.
In addition to the Bingham mine exhibit, we perused the other works on display from the permanent collection. I agree that Salt Lake can and should have a more extensive art museum, but we are pleased with what we have. From the display of the history of the museum in the cafe it is clear that there are many works in storage that could be displayed were there more space and personnel, for instance it referred to a vast collection of Navajo weavings in the permanent collection. I want to see them! It also mentioned a collection of Chinese porcelain. What is in storage that was NOT mentioned!!!
As far as current displays, it seems rather heavy on South Pacific island works. We found the variety and quality of paintings from American and European artists to be quite broadly represented. The biggest surprise to me was a video performance work. Usually I scoff, since I consider myself somewhat of a provincial...but it actually captivated me as I took time to watch it. So the museum opened my mind to something new on a rainy Saturday. I loved that about it. Well worth the visit.

This is a lovely museum that you can easily enjoy 1 1/2-2 hours exploring. I suggest taking one of the short tours to get you well acclimated and then take off on your own. They have a very nice cross selection of works and they rotate stored works to keep things changing. There is also a very nice restaurant and gift shop.
_source.review_title: A great variety and changes often.

_source.comment: Unfortunately I did not have time for a full walk-about but I did spend time in the gift store and ate at the cafe. Both are excellent. Kudos to the buyer for the Museum store - saw several unique items and the manner of display made it fun to walk around. At the cafe I had the apple & brie baguette. YUM! I will definitely return - UMFA has late hours on WED for the business travellers.

The Utah Museum of Fine Arts is located on the campus of the University of Utah in Salt Lake City. It is easy to find with signs along the main road. There is limited parking across the street from the museum as well as near the main entrance. Unless there is a football game, I wouldn't expect parking to be much of an issue however. The regular adult price for admission is $7, with discounts for senior citizens and children. Entrance is free for members of the military. However at $7 the museum is still worth it.
The museum is small but still provides an excellent selection of paintings and sculptures. Unlike many art museums in the US, this one actually has quality works by famous artists. You will not find any abstract or "art done by monkeys" here. They have temporary exhibits that rotate, but don't know how often.
They have a selection of Native American, US, Pacific Islands, ancient Egypt, Rome, and others in different rooms. While I was there they had a temporary exhibit titled: Bierstadt to Warhol: American Indians in the West, which was one of the better collections of art about the depiction of Native Americans I have seen at a small museum. The Native American There are signs that provide a background of the artist and the themes which help for those of us not familiar with them. There is also a free audio guide available, but didn't use it due to time restrictions.
The museum is open everyday except for Mondays and holidays. This makes it convenient for those looking for something to do on a Sunday. There is also a small cafe and store inside the museum. Photography is allowed throughout as long as you do not use a flash. I would definitely recommend the Utah Museum of Fine Arts. You can take as much time as necessary, but would plan on at least an hour or two.
We actually went here with friends. One of our friends had donated art to this museum so we enjoyed a personal tour with the director and curator. Enjoyed a wonderful lunch after at the museum cafe.
_source.review_title: Good cafe at the museum too

_source.comment: This is a very good museum on the campus of the U. of Utah with free visitor parking. The interior design is spectacular with a center gallery that is 2 to 3 stories high and dramatic stairs leading to the 2nd floor. The art work is eclectic. Excellent American and Western art--Remington Bronco Buster, Dixon, Gilbert Stuart, Sargent, etc. European art was OK, but not great. Interesting temporary exhibits, especially Levitt photographs. This place is worth a viist and is is a member of the North American Reciprocal Museums (NARM) so it is free to members of other museums. There is also a small cafe.
_source.review_title: Very good art museum with striking interior on university campus

_source.comment: This is a nice museum in a nice building; no flashy architecture by starchitect like gehry or libeskind but self-effacing building shows art very well. they do not have big name art like picasso or monet but small though comprehensive collection of european and american paintings as well as sculpture from asia and africa. full details on their website. i did not eat at their cafe. free parking. great place to spend a few hours if you like art museums.

On a hot July Thursday,I spent a delightful day perusing its fine samples of paintings and Art produced by European Painters.European favorites that day were Master of Santa Maria De La Hoz'"Saint john the Baptist"(Spanish Renaissance),Polidoro di Bartolomeo's"Crucifixion with Saints"(Italian Renaissance),Pier Francesco Foschi's"Young Man Weaving Wreath of Flowers"(High italian Renaissance),Pieter Breughel the Younger's"Maypole Dance"(Flemish Baroque),Melchior D'Hondecoeter's"Birds in Landscape"(Dutch Master),Charles Lebrun's tapestry."Queens of Persia At Foot of Alexander The Great"(18th Century),Gian Paolo Paninni's"Capriccio with Roman Ruins"(Italian Neoclassical),Etienne De Lavalle's"Anacreon,Eros,Sappho,and Female Dancer"(18th French),Jean Leon Gerome's"Christian's Last Prayer"(French Naturalism)Narcise De La Pena's"Forest Pool"(French Barbizon),and Armand Guillaumin's"Le Maison Nannette a Crozant"(French Expressionism).
I also savored their fine samples of American Paintings and Art.Personal American favorites that day included John Copley's"John,2nd Viscount"(tip top Mannerism),Theodore Butler's"Honfleur"(quality Pointillism),Ralph Blakelock's"Silvery Night",Birger Sandzen's"2 Pines"(American Expressionism),Conrad Buff's"Canyonlands"(American Regionalism),Thomas Moran's"Wilhelmina Pass,Weber Canyon,Utah",and Louise Farnsworth's"Blue Shadows"(American Regionalism by Utah Painter).
I also relished their fine collection of Antiquities from India such as;North India "Vishnu and Avatars"(12th Century Varanasi)"Shiva With Parvati(10th Century),and "Shiva,Lord of Dance".I also enjoyed studying their Antiquities from China(Guan Yin,Ming)
I spent a very productive day at one of the better university art museums in this region of the United States..I also liked the ambience of this art museum.
_source.review_title: One Fine Day Perusing Quality Art

_source.comment:
Wanting to take my kids to a museum during covid has been a challenge. With this museum being open, affordable, and showing a few pieces from the Smithsonian; I thought it would be a good fit for my family.
3/4 of the art work showed nudity or semi nudity. So having children meant constant giggling or covering of eyes.
I was aware from their website that this museum believes in showing all sorts of art work. But every corner we turned showed more and more nudity work.
So I suggest to go elsewhere if thats not your thing.

We were able to comfortably go through the museums exhibits in just a couple of hours. The museum has a nice feel. Their collection touches on a wide variety of topics. We especially enjoyed the very ancient artifacts and works from Mexico and Central America, and more recent tribal works from Indonesia. They also have a couple of interesting 18th-century paintings with musical iconography.

Okay, it is not the Metropolitan Museum or the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, but the UMFA is well worth the visit: there are some truly wonderful works of art on the one hand, and on the other the less than wonderful are deeply instructive. Signature, lighting, and installation are outstanding.
The small collections of objects from around the world are fascinating, and many of these objects are thrilling masterpieces.
The building itself is a massive airy sculpture.
_source.review_title: Very Interesting Museum and a Beautiful Building: Well Worth the Visit

_source.comment: This is not a large museum but I enjoyed my visit. The building itself is quite artistic with a huge flight of stairs and a room of ribbons hanging from the ceiling. Though I am not really that into art I liked it.

Visited the Utah Fine Arts in September on a trip to Salt Lake City. They showing an exhibit on Rural English Landscape Painters which was outstanding. The whole arrangement was well done and spent an enjoyable afternoon there. The cafeteria there is also very pleasant so make a day of it and eat there. The physical facility is new and very large. Well worth your time. They had something for everyone
This museum was very peaceful on a hot August afternoon. There are lovely Old Master paintings and changing exhibits. The caf was a nice place to relax with a cold drink.

I was impressed by the quality of this art museum on the University of Utah Campus. It is located in the Marcia and John Price Building on campus.
There are different sections in the gallery focusing on high quality art. Much of the art I knew and was impressed by the selection. They have art that focuses on the ancient and classical world, European and American masterworks, Asian art, art of Utah and the American West, and modern and contemporary art. My personal favorite was the art of Utah and the American West which had some stunning pieces.
There is an admission charge to the galleries.
One can park for free across the street from the Utah Museum of Fine Arts. The parking places are highlighted. One does need to register the car's license plate with the staff at the ticket desk at the gallery.
_source.review_title: High Quality Art collection - Utah Museum of Fine Arts

_source.comment:
This is a little, unexpected, gem. Unexpected, because I didn't think that there would be a museum in Salt Lake City with such high quality, and eclectic, collections. Gem, because it was really great.
From what I gather, the collections were largely the work of one person, who collected, and probably funded, the works on display, over a 20 year or so period.
The spaces for each exhibit are thoughtfully done. Some spaces are smaller than others, yet the displays are excellent, each piece well exhibited, and there is no feeling that works are crammed together.
Eclectic, because there is a huge range of exhibits, time periods, cultures. The Oceania Exhibit is small, with each piece of high quality, and some are simply about as good as they get. Ditto for the small exhibit of Buddhist art. The European paintings are excellent.
We planned on spending a couple of hours, and decided that we had to return for another visit. The museum merits minimally 3 hours.
This would be a great place for a kid to come to time and again, for short periods, to gain an understanding of the huge variety of cultures, periods and art, that the world has to offer. But, then, I am recalling my own early experiences, being taken to museums by my parents, where I was first exposed to the amazing variety of eras, cultures and art.
I should add that the staff are all very friendly, and made us feel welcomed.

The Museum opened at 11am on Sunday and there were very few people there, which allowed me to take my time at the exhibits that I most enjoyed. They offer a good mix of kinds of art, with a larger exhibit of natural Utah Indian artifacts.

We have visited the UMFA a few times for special exhibits. Recently we had wanted to see the exhibit on the Bingham Canyon mine. It was very well done, including works from the museum's collection along with borrowed works from various sources. It piqued an interest in us about the process of curating a special exhibit.
I would suggest that parking could be better marked and explained. The building itself is great with easy access. There is a cafe available, although we did not eat there. We took a quick walk through the gift shop and found it to be very interesting, having some unique items for sale.
In addition to the Bingham mine exhibit, we perused the other works on display from the permanent collection. I agree that Salt Lake can and should have a more extensive art museum, but we are pleased with what we have. From the display of the history of the museum in the cafe it is clear that there are many works in storage that could be displayed were there more space and personnel, for instance it referred to a vast collection of Navajo weavings in the permanent collection. I want to see them! It also mentioned a collection of Chinese porcelain. What is in storage that was NOT mentioned!!!
As far as current displays, it seems rather heavy on South Pacific island works. We found the variety and quality of paintings from American and European artists to be quite broadly represented. The biggest surprise to me was a video performance work. Usually I scoff, since I consider myself somewhat of a provincial...but it actually captivated me as I took time to watch it. So the museum opened my mind to something new on a rainy Saturday. I loved that about it. Well worth the visit.

This is a modest-scale museum. The notable building is a fine display space. The permanent collection is limited in scope, but still manages to come up with some pleasant surprises. I found its array of American art to be quite serviceable. And the temporary exhibit on the Bingham Mine managed to be moving: and not just earth-moving! While a city the size of Salt Lake should certainly be able to support a greater arts effort, this is certainly a fine basis on which to build.
Note: calling this the greatest art museum in Utah is unfortunately very faint praise indeed.

the classical art and furniture is very nice but the collection is quite small. They had a nice exhibit about the Kennecott copper mine in Bingham which I had seen from the airplane. I had never seen such a large hole in the ground and had wondered what that was. This was the largest open pit copper mine in the world, visible from the space station but had a landslide in 2013 which forced them to close the mine. Nice little exhibit about the mine for those interested in such things. Took campus bus from here over to the museum of natural history for free.

Unfortunately I did not have time for a full walk-about but I did spend time in the gift store and ate at the cafe. Both are excellent. Kudos to the buyer for the Museum store - saw several unique items and the manner of display made it fun to walk around. At the cafe I had the apple & brie baguette. YUM! I will definitely return - UMFA has late hours on WED for the business travellers.

I have visited art museums around the world from the greatest to the smallest and would rate this one as mediocre for a city the size of Salt Lake. I lived in Salt Lake for eight years in the 1980s and concur with the opinion that the visual arts do not receive all that much attention. The permanent collection has a few nice works in several galleries painted in a garish orange that detracts from the paintings. The two special exhibits of note were paintings of the Great Salt Lake and contemporary prints. As an art aficionado, I spent a pleasant enough two hours but will repeat that a major urban center deserves a better art museum. The Swope Art Museum in Terre Haute, Indiana, a city with a metro population of 170,000, has a more impressive permanent collection. This museum certainly doesn't even come close to matching the Toledo Museum of Art in the city where I grew up.
_source.review_title: Good for Salt Lake but Still Average

_source.comment: Price was right on Saturday (free). Native American subjects dominate, but overall it is well done. Building is beautiful.
_source.review_title: Nice Place for a Short Visit

_source.comment:
The Utah Museum of Fine Arts is located on the campus of the University of Utah in Salt Lake City. It is easy to find with signs along the main road. There is limited parking across the street from the museum as well as near the main entrance. Unless there is a football game, I wouldn't expect parking to be much of an issue however. The regular adult price for admission is $7, with discounts for senior citizens and children. Entrance is free for members of the military. However at $7 the museum is still worth it.
The museum is small but still provides an excellent selection of paintings and sculptures. Unlike many art museums in the US, this one actually has quality works by famous artists. You will not find any abstract or "art done by monkeys" here. They have temporary exhibits that rotate, but don't know how often.
They have a selection of Native American, US, Pacific Islands, ancient Egypt, Rome, and others in different rooms. While I was there they had a temporary exhibit titled: Bierstadt to Warhol: American Indians in the West, which was one of the better collections of art about the depiction of Native Americans I have seen at a small museum. The Native American There are signs that provide a background of the artist and the themes which help for those of us not familiar with them. There is also a free audio guide available, but didn't use it due to time restrictions.
The museum is open everyday except for Mondays and holidays. This makes it convenient for those looking for something to do on a Sunday. There is also a small cafe and store inside the museum. Photography is allowed throughout as long as you do not use a flash. I would definitely recommend the Utah Museum of Fine Arts. You can take as much time as necessary, but would plan on at least an hour or two.

I stopped off to see the car display. They had one of the 6 Ford Daytona Coupes on display for a short while. They also had a couple of Dusenburgs.
We looked at a little of the art display and it was well chosen also.
It wasn't too easy to find, the signage was quite small and confusing. The building is nice, with some permanent exhibits along with visiting ones. Rather small, but it is trying!

Unfortunately, there is not much of a visual arts tradition in Utah. This means that the museum lacks a base of cultured donors like the ones responsible for great museums in other provincial U.S. cities (Toledo, Ohio springs to mind, among others.) The quality of paintings and sculptures is low. The exhibits are good for elementary kids who need some art exposure. The curator does have a remedial plan, which is to concentrate on contemporary art. This is a good plan, because there is lots and lots of contemporary art to be found, and nobody knows if it is good or bad until the curator tells them.

This is a very good museum on the campus of the U. of Utah with free visitor parking. The interior design is spectacular with a center gallery that is 2 to 3 stories high and dramatic stairs leading to the 2nd floor. The art work is eclectic. Excellent American and Western art--Remington Bronco Buster, Dixon, Gilbert Stuart, Sargent, etc. European art was OK, but not great. Interesting temporary exhibits, especially Levitt photographs. This place is worth a viist and is is a member of the North American Reciprocal Museums (NARM) so it is free to members of other museums. There is also a small cafe.
_source.review_title: Very good art museum with striking interior on university campus

_source.comment: We wanted to go here when we visited Utah last year but the only day we had free then was a Monday and they don't open on Mondays. We had a voucher from a leaflet and were able to get one free entry so bith got in for $7. There were some great things to see with quite a range of stykes and cultures. The only bit we didn't enjoy was the Salt 1 exhibit - we couldn't see any artsitic value in a part-used toilet roll or an empty suitcase.

This is a nice museum in a nice building; no flashy architecture by starchitect like gehry or libeskind but self-effacing building shows art very well. they do not have big name art like picasso or monet but small though comprehensive collection of european and american paintings as well as sculpture from asia and africa. full details on their website. i did not eat at their cafe. free parking. great place to spend a few hours if you like art museums.

I also savored their fine samples of American Paintings and Art.Personal American favorites that day included John Copley's"John,2nd Viscount"(tip top Mannerism),Theodore Butler's"Honfleur"(quality Pointillism),Ralph Blakelock's"Silvery Night",Birger Sandzen's"2 Pines"(American Expressionism),Conrad Buff's"Canyonlands"(American Regionalism),Thomas Moran's"Wilhelmina Pass,Weber Canyon,Utah",and Louise Farnsworth's"Blue Shadows"(American Regionalism by Utah Painter).
I also relished their fine collection of Antiquities from India such as;North India "Vishnu and Avatars"(12th Century Varanasi)"Shiva With Parvati(10th Century),and "Shiva,Lord of Dance".I also enjoyed studying their Antiquities from China(Guan Yin,Ming)
I spent a very productive day at one of the better university art museums in this region of the United States..I also liked the ambience of this art museum.
_source.review_title: One Fine Day Perusing Quality Art

_source.comment: They have art from all times and all over the world. You'll find Renaissance, religious art, modern art, art from Asia, Africa, Central America. I liked the art from Central America of course because I'm from there; also the one from China and Egypt. I'll go again on the first Wednesday of November because it's free. The floors are wooden. This place is so exquisite. Only allowed to take pictures without flash so be careful because it's art and art is beautiful and important. U of U students enter for free with their ID but I'm a mother.
My daughter and I enjoyed going to the museum on a cold winter day. We practically had the place to ourselves and it was fantastic!
Great venue for wedding plus able to wander around the art exhibition between wedding breakfast and evening reception

Visited the Utah Fine Arts in September on a trip to Salt Lake City. They showing an exhibit on Rural English Landscape Painters which was outstanding. The whole arrangement was well done and spent an enjoyable afternoon there. The cafeteria there is also very pleasant so make a day of it and eat there. The physical facility is new and very large. Well worth your time. They had something for everyone
This museum was very peaceful on a hot August afternoon. There are lovely Old Master paintings and changing exhibits. The caf was a nice place to relax with a cold drink.

After reading that they had 18000 objects from around the world, I was disappointed. I went in the late morning and school groups at most exhibits. The exhibits on the Indians and Mummies (small) were interesting but no unforgettable pieces.
This museum is easy to walk to from the South Campus Trax station.
_source.review_title: Expected more. Glad it was part of Connect PASS.

_source.comment: Beware of what you purchase here. You may think you are buying locally made Indian items and I found stickers on many pieces from Indonesia. I was very disappointed.
_source.review_title: Items being sold here were from other countries for the most part

_source.comment:
The UMFA is located on the University of Utah campus, readily accessible from downtown SLC via the TRAX red line (I used the Stadium stop but South Campus might be okay too). The museum is not huge but there is good space to accommodate touring exhibits plus the permanent collection. The latter focuses on painting but there is a small diversity including art from India, Pacific Islands, Egypt and some other parts of the world. Keep an eye out for some interesting contemporary exhibitions.
Full adult admission is $14 (discounts for seniors, students, etc). This is waived for North American Reciprocal Museums members. Also, general admission is free on the first Wednesdays and third Saturdays each month.
_source.review_title: Utah does have some fine arts; worth a visit

_source.comment: the classical art and furniture is very nice but the collection is quite small. They had a nice exhibit about the Kennecott copper mine in Bingham which I had seen from the airplane. I had never seen such a large hole in the ground and had wondered what that was. This was the largest open pit copper mine in the world, visible from the space station but had a landslide in 2013 which forced them to close the mine. Nice little exhibit about the mine for those interested in such things. Took campus bus from here over to the museum of natural history for free.

After reading that they had 18000 objects from around the world, I was disappointed. I went in the late morning and school groups at most exhibits. The exhibits on the Indians and Mummies (small) were interesting but no unforgettable pieces.
This museum is easy to walk to from the South Campus Trax station.
_source.review_title: Expected more. Glad it was part of Connect PASS.

_source.comment: Wendover Willie - Nickname given to it from a time well into the late 1950's. The memories rooted into my mind of the many times my parents took us as kids on drives are truly PRICELESS in our De Soto sedan and yes, stopping by what was then THE STATELINE casino for a lunch. A treat indeed for us and for you? A travel back in time through a picture.. Enjoy :)
_source.review_title: a truly historic icon marker and traveller stop for photo

_source.comment: We had a wonderful time celebrating a friend's 60th Birthday! Good food, good friends and alot of laughs.

Mr. Will is pretty cool. Big ol' cowboy statue/sign, made of neon. He is pretty impressive during the day, but more so at night when he is all lit up.
The reception clerk at the hotel says all the locals say Mr. Will is pointing at West Wendover, the town. We took a look the morning we left, and yes, indeed, it appears he is doing so.
Good to visit for a highway stop. Food is nearby, there are casinos if you are so inclined. You can explain to your kids what he has hanging out of his mouth!
_source.review_title: Mr. Wendover Will is pretty cool.

_source.comment: They have many hotels, great workers. Friendliness about town . The hotel people go out of their way to help you and make you feel comfortable.
_source.review_title: Its a great town to visit

_source.comment: At the edge of the parking area were quite a few plaques on pedestals with LOTS of historical information on them! Also, extremely scenic area.

I remember him at the edge of town by a casino, drawing in tourists with his light up neon. Someone spent about $200,000 spent to restore and move him down the boulevard. Fun to see especially for nostalgic reasons or kids.

This is a cool, old remnant that demonstrates how interesting it must have been to travel back in the 50's and earlier. Beautiful neon welcoming you into this border town.
Wendover is usually a gas and snack stop for us, but we always make sure we at least drive by Will. There is a grassy area to the west and a few plaques. The only issue is I'm not sure where you can legally stop to get a few photos. The road isn't busy but it didn't look like there is an approved area.
_source.review_title: Great place to get out of the car and walk around

_source.comment: Wendover Willie - Nickname given to it from a time well into the late 1950's. The memories rooted into my mind of the many times my parents took us as kids on drives are truly PRICELESS in our De Soto sedan and yes, stopping by what was then THE STATELINE casino for a lunch. A treat indeed for us and for you? A travel back in time through a picture.. Enjoy :)
_source.review_title: a truly historic icon marker and traveller stop for photo

_source.comment:
This is the coolest guy EVER! We were traveling along Wendover and saw this amazing cowboy along the road. Of course we had to take pictures!
FYI: I'm in love with Wendover Will :)
I enjoyed the casino games. I was a winner with more money at the end of my trip than I took. It was fun.

Big Statue in the middle of the road. Park car safely and walk over to see front and back. It is my understanding that Wendover Will is lighted at night, see if possible. Near by is the Victory Highway Monuments to see also.
I mean, it's a neon sign. In the middle of the road. It's fun and you'll probably want to take a selfie in front of it, but that's about all.
_source.review_title: It's ok as far as signs go

_source.comment: Wendover Will is on the opposite side of town from Montego Bay, but really only about a mile away. We drove to it at night the first time. The kids thought it was really cool to see a 30 ft lit up cowboy in a "gambling" town. Completely different from our town. :) There is a grassy area at the base, so you may take pictures. We parked in front of it, just a little off of the road, which is probably not what the township wants you to do, but the traffic was very light. We hopped out very quickly and took a quick picture.
_source.review_title: If you're in the area, might as well stop by. :)

_source.comment:
We loved driving from Utah to Nevada on the old road through Wendover into West Wendover.
It was such a stark contrast literally one side old town quiet then Nevada big brash and riotously alive all summed up by Wendover Will as historically important as Vegas Vic.
A bit of history below from wiki
Pat Denner was commissioned to design the sign for the Stateline Casino in 1952. Denner had just completed the Vegas Vic sign that was erected in 1951. The sign was constructed by The Young Electric Sign Company.
Wendover Will was named after the town of Wendover and William Smith, who founded the Stateline Casino. The 63-foot-tall (19 m) sign was intended to draw travelers in from US Highways 40 and 50, later known as Interstate 80. The sign includes 1,184 feet (361 m) of neon tubing.[2] When driving east on Interstate 80 a caption under the sign reads, "This is the place," apparently in homage to Brigham Young. When driving west the caption reads, "Where the West begins".
Stop and say hi to wendover Will. Smile and wave if you must drive by. Check out the Victory road eagle and marked near by. Think of travel along this road in a wagon.

Yes, there was a version of this guy in Vegas, Reno and Wendover at one or another casino. Now he has been saved and stands on his own pedestal on the west side of town. He is just a fun deal to see. He was here when I was a kid like these grandkids. I am still impressed with the old sign after seventy years!
_source.review_title: So NIce They Saved This Guy

_source.comment: We went to see Wendover Will, which is a sign landmark for West Wendover. The sign was originally made for the Stateline Casino in 1952. West Wendover is a casino town on the Nevada/Utah border.
_source.review_title: Iconic Wendover Will, West Wendover, Nevada

_source.comment: This is one gambling town that will NOT rip you off. The people are nice and the businesses are there to serve you and not just take your money and leave you stranded.
_source.review_title: You can visit the entire town on the shuttle and it friendly and comfortable.

_source.comment: Right in the middle of the town road there is Will standing tall it's a great sight to see and you need to visit when your here.
Down the Road Right in the middle close to the Rainbow Casino Awesome to see at night all lite up It's a must to takee pictures

we went to see Wendover Bill. He is very big and in the center of the road. It was really quite amazing. They also have a welcome center there that we went in to check out. They let you know about the town, and have pictures and history about town, which I thought very interesting.
A bit crazy, but a nice welcome to the W Wendover area. The town is mostly homes for casino workers, but they do have great Smith's grocery store, and the other handy places.
Took a short walk from the Garter Casino to Wendover Will to get a few photos and to take a selfie .Couldnt miss getting a photo in front of him.
_source.review_title: Wanted a photo with Wendover Will

_source.comment: The sign is visible for miles. It's just up the road from the major SMITHS Market. It's not unusual to see people taking pictures of friends next to it.
_source.review_title: Kool sign and very interesting historical site right next to it

_source.comment: Although there is not a lot to see here, it is a nice stopover. There is a wide shoulder to pull off of the road.

West Wendover seems to be all casino's owned by the same group and little else.
When I went to the Chevron for a car wash it was surrounded by cops so I went in the morning and got a good exterior carwash
Glad Wendover Will is there. The only fun thing in a dreary Casino town.

North of Wendover Will sign, right in front of the new City building, is a historic gravel road with about seven roadside information signs about all the history of this area. Military training area, telephone wires, Lincoln Highway location, railroad tracks, pioneers crossing the salt flats, land speed records set on the salt flats. Allow an hour to read all the interesting information.
_source.review_title: Historic sign used to belong to one casino, the city fixed it up and kept it for everyone.

_source.comment:
Drove over from Utah just because I could. Stopped in Wendover, and while at the visitor center, saw a post card of Will. The lady at the visitor center proceeded to tell me his history. After that, I just had to see for myself. Pretty cool icon.
Just off the main road, so it worth the 1 minute drive up the road.
Snapped my pic with Will and headed back to SLC. Pretty cool day.
OK...its a 50' neon sign, right in the median of Wendover Boulevard...that's it! No, this isn't a day trip, however, it is another tribute to the excess of the Nevada gambling industry.
Montego Bay for the pool & Jacuzzi. Rainbow Casino for gambling and Peppermill for all around gambling
_source.review_title: Best little gambling town in Nevada

_source.comment: Resurrected and restored, Wendover will stands at the edge of casino row, waiting to be gazed at and photographed. Luckily the road he's on isn't too busy, he sits in the middle with an ambiguous space of asphalt which is unlikely a safe place to park, but deters no one from just stopping. He has two brothers made by Young Electric Sign Co: Vegas Vic, (downtown Vegas) and River Rick (Laughlin NV). A must see, and the easiest way / beacon to find Smiths, when you run out of beef jerky and bourbon.
_source.review_title: Tin and neon is at the heart of this Nevada triplet

_source.comment: Wendover sits along legendary roads of passage across the desert and salt flats. At the Montego Bay Casino, there's a restored Lincoln Hwy marker--a later alignment of the Lincoln was routed to Wendover then down to Ely. And Wendover was also along the Victory Hwy (back when roads had names not numbers), named for the WW1 veterans. Wendover Will used to sit by one of the casinos some years ago, but now he has been relocated to the west side of town, on the old highway leading out to rejoin the interstate. It's nice to see a remnant of the old road culture survive in 2015.
Whenever we drive near Wendover we always take a drive by Will...I know it's cheesy but we like driving past the welcome (or goodbye) of Wendover Will, haha

Just past the Casinos on the Wendover strips in the middle of highway 80 sits Wendover Will.He is a Carbon copy of Vegas Vic. There is a place to park and get out to see him and take pictures. We stopped in the day time and them came back at night when he is all lit up with Neon. When in Wendover you must see this.

On West Wendover Blvd. there is hardly any traffic.Easy to get around any time day or night. not to many stop lights. You might want to use the shuttle also,24 hours a day.
.
Unsure of the history of this statue, but stopped on roadside to get photo, illuminated at night too!
_source.review_title: Interesting statue on the entrance to town

_source.comment: Not a very long walk from the Rainbow and in the evening there wasn't much traffic so it was easy to get over to the statue. Not very good surrounding light for nighttime photography
Nother to share really. He just stands there when you enter town and lights up at night. The Las Vegas style downtown appeal of Front Street.

Stopped in Wendover for the night. Could see Will from the interstate so we had to go visit him. Very easy access. Very easy to grab a pic of him. His presence brought a smile to a weary traveler. Glad we stopped in!

This is really cool! Especially at night. Beautiful retro neon sign at the west end of town. Great for photos with the lights of Wendover in the background. Lights up front and back and is seen from I-80.

Big Statue in the middle of the road. Park car safely and walk over to see front and back. It is my understanding that Wendover Will is lighted at night, see if possible. Near by is the Victory Highway Monuments to see also.

Mr. Will is pretty cool. Big ol' cowboy statue/sign, made of neon. He is pretty impressive during the day, but more so at night when he is all lit up.
The reception clerk at the hotel says all the locals say Mr. Will is pointing at West Wendover, the town. We took a look the morning we left, and yes, indeed, it appears he is doing so.
Good to visit for a highway stop. Food is nearby, there are casinos if you are so inclined. You can explain to your kids what he has hanging out of his mouth!
_source.review_title: Mr. Wendover Will is pretty cool.

_source.comment: Stopped by here to take a look then came back at night to see all of the colors. Very nice welcome mascot for the city. Good place to stop for a picture.

Wendover Will is on the opposite side of town from Montego Bay, but really only about a mile away. We drove to it at night the first time. The kids thought it was really cool to see a 30 ft lit up cowboy in a "gambling" town. Completely different from our town. :) There is a grassy area at the base, so you may take pictures. We parked in front of it, just a little off of the road, which is probably not what the township wants you to do, but the traffic was very light. We hopped out very quickly and took a quick picture.
_source.review_title: If you're in the area, might as well stop by. :)

_source.comment: Wendover Will is always great to see... Shows the history of Wendover and is always bright at night.

As you ride through the town of Wendover, you will find Wendover Will at the end of the strip. This is a very large figure of a cowboy that is very welcoming and fun for children to see. We were there during the daytime. I think it lights up at night.
Down the Road Right in the middle close to the Rainbow Casino Awesome to see at night all lite up It's a must to takee pictures
It was probably in a better spot in its original place at the border but it still looks good where it is now. Easy to take a good photo day or night and worth the effort.

West Wendover seems to be all casino's owned by the same group and little else.
When I went to the Chevron for a car wash it was surrounded by cops so I went in the morning and got a good exterior carwash
Glad Wendover Will is there. The only fun thing in a dreary Casino town.

Wendover Will is an local town icon for over a century. A must see and snap a picture of the huge icon. He's arm was not moving the day I was there but the cigarette was a waving back and forth at night. Truly a great quick 2 minute stop at the end of town.
If you visit Wendover, you'll most likely spot him. He's tall and stands out, especially at night. An icon of a bygone era that still lives on.

Just past the Casinos on the Wendover strips in the middle of highway 80 sits Wendover Will.He is a Carbon copy of Vegas Vic. There is a place to park and get out to see him and take pictures. We stopped in the day time and them came back at night when he is all lit up with Neon. When in Wendover you must see this.

Wendover Will, or referred to as Bendover Bill by the gamblers is a must stop and see. Interesting, at the base of the sign are bricks inscribed with the names and dates of many of the racers that were on the Bonneville Salt Flats. Another place to see is the Enola Gay hangar at the airport. A lot of history in Wendover

On West Wendover Blvd. there is hardly any traffic.Easy to get around any time day or night. not to many stop lights. You might want to use the shuttle also,24 hours a day.
.
